content: Government organization in Singapore **Community Development Councils (CDCs)**[a] are a form of [local councils](/wiki/Local_governance) in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) that serves as a bridge between the [government](/wiki/Government_of_Singapore) and residents[b] living in designated districts. Each CDC functions as a platform for [grassroots](/wiki/Grassroots) initiatives and [community engagement](/wiki/Community_engagement), aiming to bring governance closer to the ground. The councils encourage [volunteerism](/wiki/Volunteerism), promote active citizenship and strengthen [social cohesion](/wiki/Social_cohesion) through the involvement of residents in decision-making and participation in local activities. Established in 1997, there were originally [nine CDCs](/wiki/List_of_Singaporean_Community_Development_Councils_(1997%E2%80%932001)) but this was later consolidated into five in 2001. Each council receives government funding to administer [social service](/wiki/Social_service) schemes, welfare assistance and community development programmes for residents within its district. Council boundaries are not fixed to the [regions](/wiki/Regions_of_Singapore) or [planning areas](/wiki/Planning_areas_of_Singapore) but are instead formed by grouping several [electoral constituencies](/wiki/Constituencies_of_Singapore). As such, their boundaries are fluid and subject to changes that occur with every [general election](/wiki/General_elections_in_Singapore). CDC districts should also not be confused with [town councils](/wiki/Town_Council_(Singapore)). Town councils operate at a more local level, are smaller in scale and more numerous. They are usually formed from stand-alone [single member constituencies](/wiki/Single_member_constituencies) (SMCs) and [group representation constituencies](/wiki/Group_representation_constituencies) (GRCs) or a combination of both. ## History CDCs were first proposed in 1996 by [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Singapore) [Goh Chok Tong](/wiki/Goh_Chok_Tong) during his [National Day Rally](/wiki/Singapore_National_Day_Rally) speech. He described them as a means to foster "stronger community bonds" and "enhance social cohesion" within local communities, with the broader goal of building a "tightly-knit, compassionate and self-reliant community". The CDCs were formally established in 1997 under the *People's Association (Community Development Councils) Rules 1997*, coming into effect on 29th March that year. These rules set out the functions, governance framework, organisational structure and financial provisions of the councils. They have since been amended on multiple occasions to account for adjustments to electoral boundaries as well as other administrative and procedural changes. CDCs operate under the [People's Association](/wiki/People%27s_Association) (PA), a statutory board under the [Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth](/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture,_Community_and_Youth) (MCCY). ## Organisation These are the constituencies in each of the five Community Development Council districts as of 23 May 2025: Community Development CouncilSingle Member ConstituenciesGroup Representation Constituencies[Central Singapore](/wiki/Central_Singapore_Community_Development_Council) - [Jurong East–Bukit Batok](/wiki/Jurong_East%E2%80%93Bukit_Batok_Group_Representation_Constituency) - [West Coast–Jurong West](/wiki/West_Coast%E2%80%93Jurong_West_Group_Representation_Constituency) The council boundaries follow that of the existing political divisions, with each handling between four and six [GRCs](/wiki/Group_representation_constituency) and [SMCs](/wiki/Single_member_constituency) and roughly dividing the country's population into equal parts. Each CDC is managed by a Council, which in turn is headed by an appointed [mayor](/wiki/Mayor) and has between 12 and 80 members. The members are appointed by the chairman or deputy chairman of the [People's Association](/wiki/People%27s_Association) (PA). ### Mayors Community Development Council (CDC)Current Mayor[Central Singapore](/wiki/Central_Singapore_Community_Development_Council)[Denise Phua](/wiki/Denise_Phua)[North East](/wiki/North_East_Community_Development_Council)[Baey Yam Keng](/wiki/Baey_Yam_Keng)[North West](/wiki/North_West_Community_Development_Council)[Alex Yam](/wiki/Alex_Yam)[South East](/wiki/South_East_Community_Development_Council)[Dinesh Vasu Dash](/wiki/Dinesh_Vasu_Dash)[South West](/wiki/South_West_Community_Development_Council)[Low Yen Ling](/wiki/Low_Yen_Ling) #### Reception Singapore has a total of five mayors, each responsible for a CDC in a specific district. Mayors also serve as chairpersons of their respective CDCs. According to former politician [Teo Ser Luck](/wiki/Teo_Ser_Luck), who was the mayor of the North East CDC, mayors are in charge of "laying foundation for building camaraderie within communities". However, critics question the need for five mayors in a city-state such as Singapore, arguing that the roles may be redundant and an unnecessary use of public funds. During the 2021 parliamentary debate on Budget 2021, [Leader of the Opposition](/wiki/Leader_of_the_Opposition_(Singapore)) [Pritam Singh](/wiki/Pritam_Singh_(Singaporean_politician)) of the [Workers' Party](/wiki/Workers%27_Party_(Singapore)) (WP) questioned the high salaries paid to mayors[c] and whether full-time CDC mayors were necessary, or if the positions were needed at all. Central Singapore CDC's mayor, Denise Phua, responded that she is the "only full-time CDC mayor" while the others are "part-time mayors". In 2025, Phua defended the positions again following calls from the [Singapore Democratic Party](/wiki/Singapore_Democratic_Party) (SDP) to abolish them, arguing that mayors do not "take over" the work of MPs or grassroots advisors but function as a "regional role" to "aggregate resources" and "address issues" that "individual constituencies might struggle to manage". ## Funding The CDCs are funded by an annual sum from the government directly proportionate to the number of residents living within their jurisdiction at a rate of [S$](/wiki/S$)1 per person. They are free to conduct their own fund-raising programs, which the government will match S$3 for every S$1 raised, up to a cap of S$40 million a year from 2018 financial year. Previously, the cap was S$24 million a year. The government also pays for the councils' operational costs, including that for its offices. - [Town Council (Singapore)](/wiki/Town_Council_(Singapore)) - [Community Development Council Vouchers Scheme](/wiki/Community_Development_Council_Vouchers_Scheme) ## Notes - Official site - Community Development Councils are envisaged by the [National Library Board](/wiki/National_Library_Board)
